title: Towards New Business Models in the Energy Sector based on Software-as-a-Service-Utilities and Value-added Services

We are world's number one when it comes to energy automation and we are responsible for 1/5 of the Earth energy production.
Electricity production.

Area.

Challenges in the energy sectors are the demographic dynamics.
We think that by 2020 or.
Beyond, we will have a population growth more than 7.5 billion people will live on this Earth.
Which is about 1 billion people more than left today.
We will have megacities, and we think that actually there are proposed to be 27 mega cities by 2025 and megacities are defined by more than 10 million people inhabiting inhabiting those cities.
Those are figures based on a source by the United Nations Organization.

As you all probably know that in the field of.
Annachi fuels or or yeah.
The fossil fuels.
Excuse me, probably 70% of the whole energy production is or the resources are located in just a few countries.
And we deal in this sector with a high price volatility.
That means that when there is a high demand, we have a high price.
When there's low demand, we have low price.
When there's, yeah, you're probably know that when you go to the next gas station.
A third challenge would be the climate change, so the.
The global endeavors of political organizations and political programs within the European Union itself aims at long-term reduction in CO2 emissions.
And there are a couple of other climate changes as well as the perception of the individual user.
For example, we all know that we are more interested in renewable energy nowadays than we will probably 10 or 20 years ago.
OK, um, what do you have in addition to that is that we're faced with an aging infrastructure.
This infrastructure infrastructure needs to be replaced because in the United States alone, 70% of Transformers in 60% of switch gear are over 25 years old and elsewhere in the world.
It's probably or most probably the same.
The energy networks are also aging and that also leads to growing, growing in complexity and reaching capacity limits.
So you can.
I don't know whether you notice that, but we had a couple of decades blackouts in the in the last decade.
The most famous ones was in the Great Lake area of the United States or in California, but we also had the first blackouts.
Also in Europe, one in 2003 was in northern Italy on the frontier to France.

And to give you a short impression how complex this whole value chain of Energy Trends of energy generation up to energy consumption is, I just want to give you a short introduction with the film, which takes about two minutes and I think is.
Quite nice to see.
Since man discovered electricity, the demand for electrical energy has grown steadily.
Electrical power has become the most important energy.
Carrying and demand is continuing to write up enough power.
Transmission was uni directional.
Large power stations generated power, industrial facilities and domestic households consumed it.
This has changed fundamentally becausw many consumers have become producers to the power flow is becoming increasingly bidirectional.
This is exactly what makes modern power grids highly complex.
More and more fluctuating renewable power generators are being connected to the grid.
However, network stability must still be maintained at all times.
Intelligent applications guarantee precise control of low pandaman.
This keeps the grid stable.
The batteries in the cars can also be used as distributed mobile energy storage devices, but how can all these factors be combined and control successfully?
The solution?
Intelligent power networks, smart grids, a large number of intelligent applications an innovative communication solutions make such highly efficient groups possible.
Smart grids insura reliable supply of electricity for our future, ecologically sound safe and efficient.

While conventional power plants generate power relatively continuously, the feed and performance of distributed generators and power generation from removal sources are considerably fluctuated as they depend on a number of influences.
Solar power from photovoltaic systems, for instance, is only available when the sun is shining, and wind farms can easily produce more power than is needed when winds are strong.
A smart grid is able to optimally balance such fluctuations and to effortlessly integrate all generators into the grid.

OK, what we saw here was a presentation of going or trans transposing from the more or less linear value chain from generation to transmission to distribution until consumption is reached of energy, which is transformed into a more or less smart energy grid as we call it.
Go beyond the.
The challenges that are interwoven with with this with this transition.
This will actually dimaond from us additional efforts at every level.
When you think of the generation, what will be different is that.
It is expected that in within the grid, the power plants will be used efficiently.
Um?
Fluctuating in Fed in feed will have to be balanced.
Blackouts are expected to be prevented, and superfluids energy is expected to be stored somewhere to be later consumed.
As transmission and distribution is considered, there will be a control of load flow, integration of distributed energy.
And as you notice, probably blackout prevention also comes here, so this isn't that easy.
It is quite a complex situation.
Where is the responsibility for avoiding a blackout in scenario in that case?
So there has to be some intelligence built within the grid and it is not decided yet whether it has to stay on this generation part or on the network part.
Um?
Officially we would opt for.
A metering and control part in the whole game.

It doesn't make sense that when we apply metering within the grid, we only take the information out from the consumer, but we also want to give them him the ability to control somehow how the energy is produced and what kind of energy is going to be consumed.
So there's an additional point into that.
When we go from one way, power flows to two way power flows.
And according to the consumption as already stated, if we want to have the flexibility to decide what we want to do, what kind of energy or electricity we want to consume.
We also have to take the responsibility to choose and.
Make actually the interactive flow control possible.
So looking at this scenario is.

Value chain as it is currently available.

Describe the business scenarios that are depicted here in in yellow, in green and blue.
Um?

Um?

Likely.
Problem.

In the vast majority of the parameters.

Is more evolutionary.
Therefore, probably more likely.

In the household and social services provided by an IT service provider, for example.
Contain in this aspect technical and process innovation as well as service and business model innovations.
In residential energy management.
